Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Strengthening the Skills of the Parent With Online Coaching
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop a machine learning-assisted family math preparation program that will help and encourage parents to provide early math instruction to young children, ages 4-8. Along with reading, developing mathematical proficiency is arguably one of the most important skills for young children to acquire, particularly with the growing importance of STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) in the world today. Yet standardized test scores in math remain alarmingly low, with just 40% of US fourth grade students performing at grade level. A considerable body of research now shows that these gaps often appear before a child first enters kindergarten. Strong parental engagement in a child's mathematics learning is often cited as a key indicator of future academic success, but ways to bring about this engagement remain elusive. Grounded both in computational social science and constructivist models of learning, this project aims to develop a scaleable means of targeting parental engagement and promoting positive math learning experiences for families, goals which are fundamentally aligned with NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and advance national welfare, and which could have significant social and economic impact for years to come.


This project will introduce several innovations, particularly in the areas of artificial intelligence and data modeling. A mobile learning application will be developed that provides users with a range of on- and off-screen math activities for parent and child to engage in together. Data will be collected from short surveys repeated at regular intervals and these will be collated together with information provided by the app (learning data, time-on-task, etc.). Deep learning approaches will be leveraged to explore relationships between content, engagement, and learning measures and to suggest follow-on activities predicted to improve these outcomes. While the data set will be limited during Phase I research, the technology will be able to identify an increasing number of connections as participation becomes more and more robust over time. In Phase II, these and other instruments will describe and detect family engagement practices at more than just one point in time, with differing socio-economic groups, and in a variety of different geographies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Parent Connect:  Strengthening the Skills of the Parent with Online Coaching

The Parent Connect mission is to increase parent engagement and encourage families to become active participants in their children’s education. The project emphasizes the importance of age-appropriate content, the power of technology and adaptive learning experiences, both goal-driven and free play, the amplifying effects of family engagement, and the critical role partnerships play in moving the needle for children at risk.

Our strategic partner in the research and development is the Parents as Teachers National Center (PATNC), a home visiting network with 1200 affiliates in all 50 states. The affiliates can reach a diverse group of over 300,000 parents (60% low SES) needed for a viable study. The PATNC has expertise in teaching adults how to be instrumental in their children's future success. Our company has considerable experience in designing technology projects for use by teachers and learning games for young children. It is expected that this collaboration will result in evidence-based research more valuable than either organization can generate on its own.

Current research indicates that specific types of parent-child interactions between the ages of 3 and 8 are the primary driver of mathematical ability through the elementary grades. Parent Connect addresses the need early on. The immediate goals are to: (1) strengthen the confidence and capabilities of the child's first teacher, the parent; (2) develop responsive relationships between parent/child and parent/coach; (3) create regular opportunities for parent and child to build early mathematical thinking, problem-solving and executive functioning skills in age-appropriate, meaningful contexts, both with and without technology; (4) reduce the stress that comes with one's child "falling behind" when lacking the skills to assist them.

The Technology: Thirty Parent Educators and 30 Affiliate Directors were interviewed to best determine product/market fit. A digital application for families and a cloud-based management system were prototyped and tested.

The digital application serves as a personal learning facilitator for activity planning and evaluation. Playful learning options range from sorting objects and building block games to backyard discoveries and location-based investigations. The entire learning experience is "gamified" with rewards, leveling-up, and special prizes designed to increase parental involvement, motivation, and learning outcomes. Parents are encouraged to take video and photos of each experience, upload them to a journal within the app, and share with friends and family on social media.

The platform enables Parent Educators to roster families and create multiple classes, communicate with parents, demo activities, and monitor progress. Analytics and machine learning algorithms provide data on usage patterns and time on task. Auto reports are sent to the Parent Educator's dashboard denoting the time each family spends on each activity, parent assessments, and performance. A color-coded matrix identifies families that have successfully completed activities as well as those experiencing difficulty.

This Phase I study: Four Parent Educators chose 10 participants from their caseload of 20. They were identified as either the "Ready Parent" (participate fully in the home-visiting program and complete "leave-behind" activities) or the "Reluctant Parent" (generally lack motivation and follow through). The families were also categorized by age range, socio-economic status, and education level completed. Families were then asked to choose and complete a minimum of 5 activities revealed on their smart phone before the next home visit or group session.

Results So Far:  All of the "Ready Parents" participated in 5 activities and posted snapshots and videos on their personal Journal page. Sixty percent of "Reluctant Parents" completed at the recommended number of activities, which is a higher percentage than is customary with "leave behind" printed activities. The remaining "Reluctant Parents" attributed their low level of participation to lack of time and/or various family problems. Additional features and incentives that appear to appeal to this group will be added and tested in Phase II.

All indications are that a game-like approach with "social media type" components will attract young parents to a greater degree than printed materials or texting apps. It also appears they will be more likely to develop better understanding of mathematical concepts and problem-solving techniques through immediate participation and online support, rather than with upfront video training or formal group instruction. Virtual awards and higher-level attainment appear to increase motivation and continued use.

Exit interviews with parents confirmed that the family application is easy to use and that they are looking forward to the addition of more games and activities. Parent Educators and PAT Directors agreed that integration of the product within the home-visiting program was feasible and could lead to greater and more frequent participation on part of parents and had the potential to expand the PATNC’s overall reach.


Last Modified: 04/01/2020
Modified by: Elizabeth A Schwartz
